item.title: [SECOAUTH-237] Use of custom custom authorization-endpoint-url can cause infinite redirect
item.description:
In certain circumstances, an infinite loop can occur when forwarding the user from the initial Authorization Endpoint authorize method to the user approval page, when using the default user approval page url of "forward:/oauth/approve_access". This url, "/oauth/approve_access", is bound to our own custom controller. We are supplying custom authorization-endpoint-url and token-endpoint-url properties and have configured the required web.xml oauth2EndpointUrlFilter as mentioned in the documentation. This is using the authorization code flow, with the built in authorization and token endpoint classes.

To replicate the error, one visits the custom AuthorizationEndpoint url. The first time here in a browser session, the user is prompted to log in, and is redirected to the appropriate user approval page. This is handled as expected by the custom controller. The user clicks the approve button and is redirected to the registered redirect url, as expected.

If the user then revisits the authorization url, generally by pasting it into the address bar on the web browser (in our case, Firefox 11), then the server goes into an infinite internal forwarding loop through the authorize method of the AuthorizationEndpoint. This method does return the appropriate ModelAndView object, with the view name set to "forward:/oauth/approve_access". However, something in the processing of this forward request fails and it ends up being mapped back to the authorize method.

In some repeatable cases, if the user instead uses the back button, then they are prompted again with the user approval page. Clicking approve on this page does allow it to continue and issue a new authorization code.

If we change user-approval-page url property to "redirect:/oauth/approve_access", leaving everything else the same, the user can then revisit the authorization url and successfully complete the flow. However, pressing the back button now causes a session binding error.

If we remove the custom authorization-endpoint-url and token-endpoint-url properties, and remove the oauth2EndpointUrlFilter from web.xml, everything works as expected. The user can both revisit the url directly and go back through the session using the back button.

Therefore, we believe the error to be somewhere in the EndpointValidationFilter class implementation of doFilter.
item.summary: Use of custom custom authorization-endpoint-url can cause infinite redirect

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.

comments.comment: I can't reproduce this, so if you can do some more analysis that would help. What is your custom authorize endpoint url? If you can see how to fix it, even better.

Dave, here is the relevant block from our servlet context:

<oauth:authorization-server client-details-service-ref="defaultOAuth2ClientDetailsEntityService" 
	token-services-ref="defaultOAuth2ProviderTokenService" token-granter-ref="connectAuthCodeTokenGranter"
 
	authorization-endpoint-url="/openidconnect/auth" token-endpoint-url="/openidconnect/token">
 
	<oauth:authorization-code authorization-code-services-ref="authCodeServices" />
 
</oauth:authorization-server>

While tracing through the application's execution during the loop, it looks like when Spring tries to look up the Handler for the user approval page at "forward:/oauth/approve_access", in the case of the infinite loop it returns the AuthorizationEndpoint.authorize method as the Handler, rather than the bean and method that we have mapped to that url. If we remove the authorization-endpoint-url and token-endpoint-url parameters from the authorization-server configuration, then the Handler lookup correctly returns our controller bean with the correct method mapped to /oauth/approve_access. Does that help? If not, let me know what kind of analysis you would need from us in order to track down what's happening.

There's a forum post from someone else with the same problem (http://forum.springsource.org/showthread.php?125099-OAuth-change-the-default-authorize-token-and-token-end-point-URLs/page2) and he doesn't mention anything to do with typing in URLs or back buttons. I still haven't seen it.

In the forum post it looks like the order of the filters was the key - the endpoint url filter has to come first. Your problem is slightly different, so I'm guessing it might be platform dependent. Are you using Tomcat? Is there a proxy? The redirect:view option seems like it might be the best one if it's something in your app server that's causing the problem.

We are using Tomcat, but not with a proxy.

I've pushed a branch up to our project's github repository that demonstrates the infinite redirect problem: https://github.com/jricher/OpenID-Connect-Java-Spring-Server/tree/Custom_URL_Infinite_Redirects. If you could take a look at our spring-context.xml and see if it looks like we're doing something wrong in the configuration, we would appreciate it. Our current head version is working, using the default URLs: https://github.com/jricher/OpenID-Connect-Java-Spring-Server. We do still want to have custom URLs eventually so we'd like to get this working. If you want, we can set up a meeting and do screen-sharing to show you (or someone else from the team) how it's failing. If so let me know and we can set that up.

There are some minor wrinkles in your sample (some should be harmless). I think this is redundant:

		<security:intercept-url pattern="/openidconnect/**" access="ROLE_USER" /> <!-- This is superceeded by the /oauth/token pattern above -->

But I'm worried about pattern="/openidconnect/token" (since the filter that modifies the URL comes before the Spring Security filter). However that doesn't explain why it sometimes works (I would expect the token grant to always fail).

And the web.xml has filter definitions interleaved with filter mappings (Tomcat is tolerant of that).

Does your client use header or form parameters to send the client credentials? Maybe there is a filter ordering problem there as well? Again I can't explain in that case why it sometimes works and sometimes not.

Finally, I'm not really clear on steps to reproduce. If you could make sparklr2 fail in the same way I would be able to follow it better. Could you do that?
Here's my customized sparklr/tonr system: https://gist.github.com/2421187. If you can break that and give me steps to reproduce that would be great.

Hi Dave,
Thanks for posting the customized sparklr/tonr system. I did manage to break it, and it only took a one-line difference: if you remove the user-approval-page="redirect:/oauth/confirm_access" statement from the authorization-server configuration on line 120 of spring-servlet.xml, the infinite redirects will happen as stated above.

Your AccessConfirmationController maps /oauth/confirm_access to a handler method; we have a similar controller that does the same. Since Spring Security defaults to looking for /oauth/confirm_access, we assumed that as long as we had a handler mapping that url pattern, it would work. However it seems that the "redirect:" bit is essential to getting this working.

I changed the user-approval-page back to the deafult and it still works fine for me (in fact it works a little better because a back button from the sparklr pics page now just reloads it instead of getting a 500 because the authorization request is missing. Sorry to be dense, but can you elaborate specifically on the steps to reproduce in the customized code (I'll push an update to gist to match the latest SECOAUTH snapshot)?

Steps to reproduce:

1) Change the authorization-server configuration as follows.
Original code, starting at line 119 of spring-servlet.xml:

<oauth:authorization-server client-details-service-ref="clientDetails" token-services-ref="tokenServices"
 
	user-approval-handler-ref="userApprovalHandler" token-endpoint-url="/token" authorization-endpoint-url="/authorize" 
        user-approval-page="redirect:/oauth/confirm_access">
 
	<oauth:authorization-code />
 
	<oauth:implicit />
 
	<oauth:refresh-token />
 
	<oauth:client-credentials />
 
	<oauth:password />
 
</oauth:authorization-server>

New code, starting at 119:

<oauth:authorization-server client-details-service-ref="clientDetails" token-services-ref="tokenServices"
 
	user-approval-handler-ref="userApprovalHandler" token-endpoint-url="/token" authorization-endpoint-url="/authorize">
 
	<oauth:authorization-code />
 
	<oauth:implicit />
 
	<oauth:refresh-token />
 
	<oauth:client-credentials />
 
	<oauth:password />
 
</oauth:authorization-server>

2) Access the authorization endpoint directly, via /sparklr2-1.0.0.BUILD-SNAPSHOT/authorize?response_type=code&client_id=my-trusted-client&redirect_uri=[insert uri here].
This brings you to the login page. Login as any user, click "approve" on the user approval page. Now the browser should redirect to your redirect_uri, with an authorization code appended to the URI.

3) Access the authorization endpoint directly again, via /sparklr2-1.0.0.BUILD-SNAPSHOT/authorize?response_type=code&client_id=my-trusted-client&redirect_uri=[insert uri here].
This causes the infinite redirect. The browser will not load the user-approval-page, and if you watch the server logs (Tomcat, in our case) you will see the request looping infinitely.
Dave, did my instructions clear things up for you? Let me know if you still can't reproduce the bug.

Thanks. Yes I can reproduce the loop by pasting those urls into my browser. It's not a very realistic scenario, and when I paste the URL from an actual successful session instead of yours, it works (or rather I get an error warning me about CSRF, which seems sensible). I'll have a look at why the loop is happening anyway and see if I can fix it.
I think I fixed this. Please try it out and let me know if you see any problems.
Thanks, that does fix the bug. Thanks for taking care of the issue.
